text:
So last month I decided to do some
coaching over the phone using a new

platform called clarity and one of the
most common questions I got asked

sounded something along the lines of
this improvement pill I've been working

really hard trying to turn my life
around I'm adopting a bunch of new

habits I'm reading books I'm working out
but I'm having issues cutting out things

like video games or watching TV or
playing on my phone for my life

completely I still find myself slacking
off from time to time what should I do

today I want to address this question
because I think a lot of people who get

into self-development approach
relaxation and things are pleasurable

the wrong way we're taught that these
things are bad so we start to believe

that we should avoid them completely but
there's a reason why certain things feel

good why junk food tastes so good why
having sex is something we all crave

while watching TV shows playing video
games and surfing the web are so

alluring because they satisfy an ancient
part of our brain let's just call it the

monkey brain to simplify things it's a
part of us that's been around for

millions and millions of years and its
main job has always been to keep us

alive junk food tastes so good because
high-calorie high-fat high-sugar foods

were scarce back then so we've evolved
to seek them out if you found a bag of

chips a million years ago it was in your
best interest to finish that bag and ask

for seconds because who knows when would
be the next time you come across such a

great source of calories the reason I'm
telling you this is because just like

how you need to feed a pet you need to
feed your monkey brain if you don't it

starts to get upset it starts to believe
that things in your life are not okay

because everything that reduces stress
everything that satisfies the monkey

brain things like food sex entertainment
socializing and discovery make us feel

good because they indicate that we are
living life correctly that we're doing

all of the right things the problem
nowadays is yes a lot of these things

have become way too accessible it's
become way too easy to get high calorie

foods way too easy to trick your brain
into thinking you're sleeping with

dozens a beautiful woman way too easy to
trick your brain into believing that

it's achieving great feats when in
reality you're just playing a video game

which has caused a lot of people to form
bad habits and even get addicted to

these pleasurable things that's a case
of feeding the monkey brain too much so

we end up getting into self-development
and we say to ourselves okay things that

are pleasurable are bad so it's obvious
I need to cut them out I'm gonna stop

feeding my monkey brain completely but
what eventually happens when you starve

your monkey brain is that it's
starts to act out I've seen this over

and over again with many of the clients
I've coached but also in my own life as

well we'll be sticking to all of our
good habits perfectly for a couple of

days or even weeks and out of nowhere
boom the monkey brain says enough is

enough I want to feel good the next
thing you know you're out there binging

on everything you've been trying to
avoid you're on autopilot shoving ice

cream down your throat don't
underestimate the monkey brain I assure

you if you don't feed it it's eventually
going to act out and cause you to

relapse so what do we need to do well we
need to incorporate pleasures into our

life that's right you should be doing
things that you enjoy things that lower

your stress things that feel good and
not just once or twice a week you should

be doing these things every single day
but of course you need to do this

correctly see there are three types of
rewards the first type are what I like

to call negative some rewards these are
things that yes can relieve a tremendous

amount of stress but will cause more
stress down the line for example

something like drinking alcohol can lead
to a very very fun night that is

definitely a huge way of relieving
stress and satisfying the monkey brain

but as we all know drinking takes a huge
toll on our body if he hydrates you it

causes most of your body functions to
slow down it messes with your sleep for

tonight the list goes on and on the
point is it causes you to relieve stress

in a moment but causes more stress down
the line another example of this is

eating junk food I can't deny ice cream
tastes great

that makes you feel pretty darn good
while you're eating it but it causes

things like a huge spike in blood sugar
which makes us feel tired and our brain

foggy once the sugar high is over again
it relieves stress in a moment B causes

more stress down the line negative some
rewards are perfectly fine to have once

in a while no more than once a week the
second type of reward are what I like to

call zero-sum rewards these are rewards
that don't really have serious negative

consequences and don't really cause more
stress down the line the problem with

them is that they don't relieve a lot of
stress and also take up a lot of time

that's why I call it zero-sum because
you gain a bit but you also lose a bit

and this includes things like playing
video games watching TV shows and

browsing the Internet now you have to be
careful about the internet because it

all depends on what you're browsing if
you're on Reddit looking at funny videos

that's perfectly fine but if you're on
Instagram comparing yourself to others

that's actually a negative
reward your reward is the dopamine rush

you get from gathering new information
but you end up stressing yourself out

when you look at all those photoshopped
images of people who live supposedly

better lives than you so it causes more
harm than good so you have to be very

careful about that
now zero-sum rewards are perfectly fine

to include in your life every day you
just have to be careful because they do

take up a lot of time so it's easy to
overdo it 1 to 2 hours of video games

and television every day in my opinion
is a-ok because it's still a good way to

relieve some stress and satisfy that
monkey brain even though it's only a bit

but there are better alternatives which
brings us to the final type of reward

positive some rewards these are
extremely powerful rewards with a lot of

benefits they reduced your levels of
stress tremendously with no consequence

and they also tend to reduce your levels
of stress later on a good example of

this is something like a deep tissue
massage massages feel great in the

moment they have been clinically proven
to reduce things like cortisol which is

directly related to stress they also
help with things like muscle recovery so

if you're someone who goes to the gym a
lot it's going to help reduce stress

down the line another example of this is
good food I like to eat a huge grass-fed

steak just about every single day it's
one of my favorite meals in the world it

makes me feel amazing but because it's
high-quality meat it helps me feel good

and energized for the rest of the day
high quality meat like this helps keep

my hormone level stable which in turn
prevents stress and problems down the

line one more example of this just to
drill in the point is spending time with

a loved one spending a night with your
significant other has been proven to

release hormones such as oxytocin and
endorphins which both significantly

reduce stress levels and feel pretty
darn good studies have even found that

there is an apparent 48-hour afterglow
after a fun night with a loved one which

means your stress levels decreased
drastically during the night but also

for a couple of days after all right so
now that we know all about the different

types of rewards let's talk about
satisfying the monkey brain the best way

to feed the monkey brain is by adopting
a mentality of work hard play hard it's

good that you're trying to improve all
of these areas of your life but remember

all of this change is stressful so you
need to be rewarding yourself whenever

you do a good job for example I like to
reward myself with good food after a

hard workout at the gym I do this every
single time I work out because when you

give yourself the same reward after
doing something hard

it eventually forms into a habit every
habit needs a routine which is the hard

thing you need to do like going to
Jim and a proper reward that follows

soon after which in my case is a
delicious meal without a good reward the

habit will never form that's right it's
impossible to form new habits without

good rewards if you'd like to learn more
about how habits work you can check out

the tamed course which is absolutely
free which I will link to in the

description box below what's important
is that you don't fall into the Hail

Mary mindset that most people in the
self-development field feed you because

it simply does not work well it works
for a while until your monkey brain gets

sick of it and goes out of control the
key here is to keep the monkey brain

happy and well-fed so that he will not
disturb you if you do it enough times

he'll even say hey can we do that
working out thing again because I'm

craving some good food yes the monkey
brain will start to crave all the

working out and the reading and the hard
work because it starts to believe that

it will get fed a good reward after so
yes

work hard improve your life but make
sure you reward this hard work with

positive some rewards often zero some
rewards once in a while and negative

some rewards once in a blue moon keep
your monkey well fed with strategically

timed slacking off and you will make
huge amounts of progress without many

issues this episode's brought to you to
help the guys at Skillshare like I just

mentioned you should only be rewarding
yourself after you do something that is

challenging which includes learning and
skill share is a great place to do just

that they have over 22,000 courses on a
wide variety of topics from photography

to videography to business and even
writing these are all skills that if you

work on can lead to huge benefits down
the line I suggest you find something

that you are genuinely interested in and
learn more about that over at skill

share a membership with them usually
cost about $10 per month but I've

managed to work out a deal with them the
first 300 people to sign up using the

link in the description box below and
get access to skill share for two months

absolutely free alright so one of the
courses that I've been getting into is

kind of random it's the fundamentals of
magic tricks which is something that

I've always found fascinating so I
decided why not I'm going to learn it

it's challenging and it acts as a great
way to entertain my friends whenever I

see them and let me tell you seeing the
look on their face when I blow their

mind is definitely a positive summer
besides that guys stay tuned
